Award.AwardTitle: New Model and Methodology for Signal Estimation and Decoding

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to apply nonlinear dynamics to the study of (iterative) statistical inference, an important class of algorithms with well-proven applications in communications, signal processing and artificial intelligence. Existing models and methodologies for iterative analysis, coming largely from an information theoretical perspective, are inadequate in predicting and controlling the individual (rather than the ensemble-average) time-evolution behavior of a large-dimension and highly-dynamic signal sequence. On the other hand, estimating nonlinear dynamical systems, especially the challenging case of chaos, has not taken advantage of the powerful tool of statistical inference nearly as much as it could have. A wide spectrum of activities are planned to bring together the important ideas and tools from these two fields, to supply each other with new perspectives and new approaches, and to hopefully generate a whole new engineering methodology for unifying classical signals and chaotic signals. Specific focus will be set on understanding the cause and impact of chaotic behavior in statistical inference, developing ways to control chaos and transient chaos, and using statistical inference on appropriate models, such as Markov random fields and factor graphs, to predict and synchronize chaotic systems.

In view of the very pervasive scope of the practical applications associated with statistical inference algorithms and nonlinear dynamical theory, the research work in the proposed direction will have significant societal and scientific impacts. The potential application is broad, including many communication systems and discrete dynamical systems, such as cellular networks, wireless sensor and ad-hoc networks, digital data recording systems, radar systems, weather and tornado prediction, ecology, and population estimation. The proposed research also integrates a meaningful education and outreach component, which includes opening a series of seminars, supplying undergraduate and graduate students with theses projects, developing a new graduate level course, and engaging under-represented students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project cross-fertilizes the areas of communications and the non-linear dynamical systems theory (especially the chaos theory) by bringing useful communication and conventional signal processing ideas to chaotic signals and systems, and bringing useful chaotic systems ideas to communications and signal processing. The chaos theory, as one of the “Three Theories of the 20th Century”, has been shown to find a wide-spread application in modeling and predicating natural phenomena and physical processes. In the area of information and communication, however, the existing research that applies the chaos theory to communication systems focuses primarily on improving communication security. In this project, we took a new and different perspective and explored the practicality of “order and reliability out of chaos.”

Through theoretical analysis, algorithmic study, and software simulation, we investigated and developed new ways to use the theories and tools from the dynamical systems to model, characterize control and improve the dynamical behavior of iterative probabilistic inference algorithms, a very important class of algorithms that finds wide applications in many error correction codes, modulators and equalizers. Our most exciting outcome is the invention of new ways to construct novel analog error correction codes (AECC) as well as digital error correction codes (DECC). Some of our new AECC, by seamlessly embedding quantization in digital coding can perform on par with the best-known error correction codes to-date, yet with lower complexity!

The chaos-based AECC developed here are specifically useful for communication applications with one or more of the following three aspects: voluminous analog data (e.g. sensor outputs, bio-imaging data), limited bandwidth provision, limited maximum transmit power (e.g. solar powered transmitter). Under these situations, the new codes may even outperform the best digital codes (e.g. turbo codes with unequal error protection). Noteworthy examples include high-resolution bio-images in vivo, such as ultra-sound, MMR, CT images and especially 3-D Optical coherence tomography (OCT). Additionally, this project has a potential impact on physical resources (i.e. bandwidth and energy) that form the information infrastructure (e.g. the Internet-of-Things, the smart electric grid).
